issues.title: Rename '.*ID' options to '.*Id'

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
layered: #646 rename options *ID -> *Id

Usually the naming convention during camel case is to capitilize only
the first letter of things such as "ID" etc.
Also, it fits the melk code generator better.

issues.title: More flexible port label positioning
issues.body:
Is there a way to force the label of a port always on the same side? For example in the model below all port labels are bottom right and bottom left. There is only one exception highlighted in red.

![wrong label position](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/61700870/82894456-e537de80-9f52-11ea-8d9b-aa09a932c403.png)

I was expecting that setting "elk.nodeSize.constraints" to PORT_LABELS would expand the Dashboard node to fit the label in the same position.

issues.title: Rename northOrSouthPort layout option
issues.body:
Lets change it to something that's user-friendly and independent of the layout direction. The option is active when port constraints are either `FREE` or `FIXED_SIDE`. 

I feel it's hard to come up with an intuitive name though as we don't have defined terms for the different ports. Maybe one could call them _flow_ and _non-flow_ ports. The first one being those ports that are in line with the flow of the graph, i.e. the layout direction. 

Maybe: 
`option allowNonFlowPortsToSwitchSides`

Furthermore, the documentation should include the fact the the backing algorithms only aims at reducing edge crossings, not edge length. 

Opinions?

issues.title: Layouter id for rectPacking inconsistent
issues.body:
Take a look at https://www.eclipse.org/elk/reference/algorithms.html 

Usually a layouter's id starts with `org.eclipse.elk.` and adds a single element for the layouter, e.g.
```
org.eclipse.elk.layered
org.eclipse.elk.mrtree
```

For the rectangle packing this is different: `org.eclipse.elk.rectpacking.rectPacking`.

I propose to align it to the common case.

issues.title: Switch from extension points to service loaders
issues.body:
The KIELER Semantics project recently wanted to make their project more independent of Eclipse infrastructure. As a part of that, they changed the way their software components are registered. What used to be done through the standard extension point mechanisms is now done via Java service loaders which are used when running in the Eclipse context as well.

I think it would be worthy to investigate this for registering meta data providers. As of now, using ELK in plain Java mode requires clients to register meta data providers themselves, which is unfortunate. Switching to a service loader mechanism would only require them to call an initialization method instead, if at all.

What I cannot judge yet are the implications for the JavaScript version of ELK. I believe that uses a different registration mechanism anyway, but @uruuru may have to correct me there.

**Tasks**

- [x] Introduce basic service loading mechanism
- [x] Update documentation
- [x] Update New Project wizard
- [x] Add unit tests to check whether the expected layout algorithms are properly registered

Test: Register meta data providers explicitly again. #402

There seems to be a problem with our Tycho-Surefire test harness. The
service loader does not see the service provider definitions, as is the
case when we start an Eclipse-based runtime. However, the ELK Service
plug-in probably is not loaded either and thus cannot fix the problem.
Instead of fixing our test harness, we simply revert to registering the
meta data providers explicitly, which is way easier.

issues.title: Ensure margins are strictly >= 0.
issues.body:
From a PR, comments from me and cds (in that order): 

> The issue is due to double imprecision and the >= comparison used in the test. Using a fuzzy compare with an epsilon in the test would solve the issue. @le-cds shall we do that or do you think the margins should strictly have no negative sign?
>> I find negative margins really quite irritating. I think my preferred solution would be to ensure they are at least 0 wherever they are set.

> Would you suggest to add a corresponding check and modification to the end of every processor that touches margins?
>> I'm dreading having to wade through that code and making it more complex, but yes, if I'm serious about my preferred solution, then this is what would have to happen. :/

issues.title: CoreOptions not registered early enough
issues.body:
To quote from #402:

> There seems to be an issue with the order in which the providers are loaded. I came across the following: In a plain Java environment the `CoreOptions` end up being loaded last. As a consequence all options registered in other layout algorithm providers via `supports` do not end up in the `knownOptions` map of the corresponding `LayoutAlgorithmData`.
> 
> I'm not sure if the bundle-based loading in `ElkServicePlugin` happens to load `CoreOptions` early enough by chance or if dependencies are resolved there.
> 
> A pragmatic solution would be to simply make sure `CoreOptions` are loaded first. The proper solution would be to leverage some dependency graph to derive the order.

issues.title: Nodes of different partitions end up in the same layer
issues.body:
Partitions are defined in the [documentation](https://www.eclipse.org/elk/reference/options/org-eclipse-elk-partitioning-partition.html) as "...a pair of nodes with different partition indices is placed such that the node with lower index is placed to the left of the other node (with left-to-right layout direction)."

While this is straight forward I'm wondering about the node order in this small [example](https://rtsys.informatik.uni-kiel.de/elklive/elkgraph.html?compressedContent=A4QwTgLgltD2B2V4HMB0IDG0BuIIFMAuAAgjAFd8AoK+WAE32PgEZiBvY0SGKBEtgBsQAI3yDiAIlaTiAX1oMm8AEwcu4aHHgk1wsROkrZCuo2YBmddy18dxAAzF94qfAsma+esmVsAtAB8zCpU3r7MAcHuQA). As it is, the node order is as expected and well reflects the partition numbers. However, if we change the partition number of n3 to '3' then n2 appears in the same layer even though n2 has a lower partition number and should be to the left according to the above definition. Interestingly the layout now is the same as with "partitioning.activate: false".

Not sure if I misunderstand partitions as a concept, so every insight is appreciated! :-)

issues.body:
Since junction points are stored as a layout option and 
 * the option has `new KVectorChain()` as default value
 * the option is checked via `getProperty()` _prior_ to exporting the layout options themselves (and thus is constructed silently)

every edge of the produced json contains the following line: 
```
"layoutOptions":{"junctionPoints":"()"}}
```

issues.body: The layout test framework's main plug-in, `org.eclipse.elk.alg.test`, has a dependency on `org.eclipse.elk.debug.grandom.ui`, since that contains the class which actually produces random graphs: `GRandomGraphMaker`. issues.title: FIXED_SIDE port constraint has incident on edge layout
issues.body:
As explained on [gitter](https://gitter.im/eclipse/elk?at=5db1b584e886fb5aa2e9e95d), I've fixed the sides of ports with "input port" to the WEST side and "output port" to the EAST side. The result corresponds to what I expect but it seems to have undesirable side effect: as if when the side of a border node is fixed, the "order" of border nodes are not the same after the result.

In my case, the result is that some edges intersect each other.

Here is an example. Sorry it is a big diagram but I not succeeded to have a minimal reproduction case. I have highlighted in red the "interesting" part.

- BigDiagram-InitialState.png : Initial state of the diagram
![BigDiagram-InitialState](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1825882/67663689-6059f780-f966-11e9-89c6-40fcaa83b17f.png)
- BigDiagram-ResultWithoutFixedSide.png: The result without having fixed the side of the ports: The edges with label 1, 2, 3 and 4, and their associated ports are "correctly" layouted and there is no edge intersection.
![BigDiagram-ResultWithoutFixedSide](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1825882/67663729-6ea81380-f966-11e9-9cd8-abac73e800a2.png)
- BigDiagram-ResultWithFixedSide.png: The result with having fixed the side of the ports: The edge with label 1 intersects all other edges.
![BigDiagram-ResultWithFixedSide](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1825882/67663713-66e86f00-f966-11e9-9c6d-053a06d9b286.png)

It seems to be a bug as there is no reason for edge with label 1 to not be the first outgoing from the node "My concerned source".

issues.title: Box layout algorithm interferes with set minumum size
issues.body:
```
node n {
	algorithm:box
	minimalNodeSize:"(60.0,60.0)"
	elk.padding:"[top=25.0,left=25.0,bottom=0.0,right=0.0]"
	node ni {
		layout[size:10,10]
	}
}
```
Drawing this graph I would expect a parent node with size 60x60 and a node inside that with a padding of 25 from the top left, putting it in the center of the 60x60 parent node.
Instead, a 35*35 node is drawn with the inner node locked in the bottom right corner.

I tracked down where this issue comes from and found [this commit](https://github.com/eclipse/elk/commit/89caa5cd53bf6a2a51534281f16702cb12cb82d1). In there, the BoxLayoutProvider was changed to not read the individual width and height and work on local copies of that, but change the x and y values of the instance stored in the minimum node size property directly. That causes the minimum size constraint to get messed with during box layout if a padding is configured. That should not happen.
The version previous to that commit looks good to me, or just to not put the values for the box layouter back into the bounds instance.

issues.title: The activation of `org.eclipse.elk.insideSelfLoops` breaks the nodeSize.constraints
issues.body:
The activation of `org.eclipse.elk.insideSelfLoops` breaks the nodeSize.constraints. More precisely, the combination of [org.eclipse.elk.insideSelfLoops.activate](https://www.eclipse.org/elk/reference/options/org-eclipse-elk-insideselfloops-activate.html) on nodes and [org.eclipse.elk.insideSelfLoops.yo](https://www.eclipse.org/elk/reference/options/org-eclipse-elk-insideselfloops-yo.html) on edges breaks the [NODE_LABELS](https://www.eclipse.org/elk/reference/options/org-eclipse-elk-nodesize-constraints.html) node size constraint.

Steps to reproduce:
* Open SampleWithEdgeInsideSelfLoopFalse.elkg in the Layout Graph view (from [SampleWithEdgeInsideSelfLoopTest.zip](https://github.com/eclipse/elk/files/3212490/SampleWithEdgeInsideSelfLoopTest.zip)). The initial graph, without layout, is like
![SampleWithEdgeInsideSelfLoop-initial](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1825882/58259121-34619700-7d74-11e9-8b8a-19af76c0a49e.png)
* The layout result is
![SampleWithEdgeInsideSelfLoop-FalseResult](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1825882/58259126-362b5a80-7d74-11e9-9a3b-4625a517af81.png)
We have the bug https://github.com/eclipse/elk/issues/425 - Wrong layout for self-loop edge but the rest is OK.
* Open SampleWithEdgeInsideSelfLoopTrue.elkg in the Layout Graph view (from [SampleWithEdgeInsideSelfLoopTest.zip](https://github.com/eclipse/elk/files/3212490/SampleWithEdgeInsideSelfLoopTest.zip)).
* The layout result is
![SampleWithEdgeInsideSelfLoop-TrueResult](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1825882/58259124-362b5a80-7d74-11e9-9e85-4052ae8e02ed.png)
We always have the bug https://github.com/eclipse/elk/issues/425 but the size of node 1 is smaller than before (**not enough** for the label size).

issues.title: Inconsistency edges layout with option hierarchyHandling set to INCLUDE_CHILDREN
issues.body:
With the algo org.eclipse.elk.layered, with the option hierarchyHandling set to INCLUDE_CHILDREN, the x coordinate of start and end points of an edge depends on other edges.

For example, in this [graph](https://rtsys.informatik.uni-kiel.de/elklive/elkgraph.html?-sM0mNbpMpiIIgh5ncnusYJttnsDscYKcLnFLpdrjAAELRK6A4FpUHZXL5XBFGGiCrVOqNZrtTq2Hr9SZY0aFFmTaazFnEpbcZ7k15U2k0umXAGhVl3TGaskUt4kL4-RZ9f7XLnpTK8yEC6FlYVwsWIyUo6VojEPeVjFkIPEqk3qqKkl6U95HE6HM6GxlIATAMJqBAkcLkcLqgC0AD5WeQ1QtojAhilsQ4c2Ns4UNSsLTqEwAOE4AVhTSHOQA), the edge E1 between the port of A and the port of B is correctly layouted: ![Correct layout screenshot](https://i.imgur.com/Np9vEnE.png)

If we add another edge between the port of A1 and the port of A2, like [this](https://rtsys.informatik.uni-kiel.de/elklive/elkgraph.html?-sM0mNbpMpiIIgh5ncnusYJttnsDscYKcLnFLpdrjAAELRK6A4FpUHZXL5XBFGGiCrVOqNZrtTq2Hr9SZY0aFFmTaazFnEpbcZ7k15U2k0umXAGhVl3TGaskUt4kL4-RZ9f7XLnpTK8yEC6FlYVwsWIyUo6VojEPeVjFkIPEqk3qqKkl6U95HE6HM6GxlIATAMJqBAkcLkcLqgC0AD5WeQ1QtojAhilsQ4c2Ns4UNSsLTqEwAOE4AVhTSEuGazACZc-mEGOi6WWeXx2Ho9XHrXRg4R42h82Y+a41baV3ab36ecgA), the layout of E1 is wrong:
* the startX is too small of 5 pixels
* the endX is too big of 5 pixels
* ![Wrong layout screenshot](https://i.imgur.com/A2SjajK.png)

To be more precise, the edge is layouted in the middle of the port not to its border. You can see that by changing the port size.

issues.title: Ports of compound graphs not fixed
issues.body:
When laying out compound graphs, ports of compound nodes should have fixed positions according to the child graphs. However, they don't, resulting in the port placement to be broken. Consider the following simple graph:

```
node N0 {
	port P0
}

node N1 {
	port P1
}

node N2 {
	port P2a
	port P2b
	port P2c
	
	node N2_1 {
		port P2_1a
		port P2_1b
	}
	
	edge P2a -> N2_1.P2_1a
	edge P2b -> N2_1.P2_1a
	edge N2_1.P2_1b -> P2c
}

edge N0.P0 -> N2.P2a
edge N1.P1 -> N2.P2b
```

The corresponding drawing in KLighD looks like this:

![klighd](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7465584/52564923-a6d1eb00-2e05-11e9-89ee-aee26e955914.png)

Note how the slanted inner hierarchical edges would be straight if the ports were at the positions originally computed for them.

The layout graph looks like this:

![layout_graph](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7465584/52564959-bd784200-2e05-11e9-9ec3-e1f14d37e4fe.png)

issues.title: Weird and unstable self loop label positions are chosen
issues.body:
The new self loop label placement code generates a number of candidate label positions for each self loop and then chooses a subset of positions such that they don't overlap. The results are currently not necessarily desirable, though:

![screen shot 2018-08-08 at 13 59 28](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7465584/43835769-6132191a-9b13-11e8-954c-958deeafcc8b.png)

First, one edge label overlaps the node, which is unfortunate. Second, refreshing the layout results in different placements. I suspect that some hash table magic is happening in the code which introduces a certain randomness into the algorithm.

issues.title: DiagramLayoutEngine#layout(...) and concurrency
issues.body:
In the context of KLighD and incremental update we currently face a concurrency issue. 

First some context: 
There are two `#layout(...)` methods within the `DiagramLayoutEngine`: [The first one](https://github.com/eclipse/elk/blob/master/plugins/org.eclipse.elk.core.service/src/org/eclipse/elk/core/service/DiagramLayoutEngine.java#L356) divides the layout task into three steps (buildLayoutGraph, layout, and applyLayout), where the first and the third step are executed on the UI thread. [The second one](https://github.com/eclipse/elk/blob/master/plugins/org.eclipse.elk.core.service/src/org/eclipse/elk/core/service/DiagramLayoutEngine.java#L486) executes the overall process in one go and on the calling thread. 

We were wondering as to why this distinction is made. One thing we could imagine is that GMF-like editors require that the access to the view model is performed on the UI thread. 

Now to problem: KLighD internally maintains a _view model_ for which a layout graph is created and laid out. It always uses the _first_ `layout(..)` method to perform the layout. Now, since the second step (of the three steps mentioned above) is executed on a different thread, the incremental update may alter the view model during the layout process. One may thing that this is not a problem since layout is performed on the previously created layout graph (which was done on the UI thread). However, before the actual layout algorithm is called, the `addDiagramConfig(...)` method 
 is invoked in [line 393](https://github.com/eclipse/elk/blob/master/plugins/org.eclipse.elk.core.service/src/org/eclipse/elk/core/service/DiagramLayoutEngine.java#L393). In KLighD's case this calls the `KLighdLayoutConfigurationStore`, which in turn accesses the original view model. 

During this it can happen that the incremental update modifies the view model and the configuration store tries to access invalid elements, which eventually yields NPEs and the likes. 

Note that the issue doesn't occur with the second `layout` method. 

An easy way to solve the issue seems to be to move the `addDiagramConfig` call into the first step, which would then _build and configure the layout graph_. 
@spoenemann any thoughts from your side?

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
core.service: #325 moved 'addDiagramConfig' to avoid concurrency issues

 - see the ticket for a more detailed explanation

This commit fixes this problem by adding the original ID as another
property to each page.

Signed-off-by: Christoph Daniel Schulze <cds@informatik.uni-kiel.de>

issues.title: NodeLabelPlacement reset for directions other than RIGHT
issues.body:
Consider this simple graph 
```
elk.direction: RIGHT

node x1 {
	nodeLabels.placement: "INSIDE V_CENTER H_CENTER"
}
node x2 {
	nodeLabels.placement: "INSIDE V_CENTER H_CENTER" 
}

edge e2: x1 -> x2
edge e1: x2 -> x1
```

Setting the direction to something other than `RIGHT` resets the node label placement as seen here:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7552459/37105373-4626e900-222f-11e8-99f2-49888f52470f.png)

The issue is that the `GraphTransformer` accidentally sets the NodeLabelPlacement of the labels to the option's default `NodeLabelPlacement.fixed` due to the side-effect in `MapPropertyHolder#getProperty(...)`.

issues.title: Minimum size calculated for hierarchical nodes is wrong
issues.body:
When ELK Layered is summoned to compute a layout for the innards of a hierarchical node, it calculates the minimum size the node will need to have to accomodate its ports, labels and the likes. If its hierarchical ports don't have connections to the inside and don't have a port side or position set, ELK Layered determines that all of them will be on the western side, leading to results such as the following:

![screen shot 2018-03-01 at 10 52 42](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7465584/36838299-1cf06b0a-1d3f-11e8-9ad3-3cd028db2309.png)

If ports P7 to P8 were correctly determined to be on the eastern side, the node's minimum height would (correctly) decrease.

issues.title: Strange surrounding port space
issues.body:
Here's a graph:

```
node N1 {
	nodeSize.constraints: "PORTS PORT_LABELS MINIMUM_SIZE NODE_LABELS"
	portConstraints: FIXED_ORDER
	
	port P1 {
		^port.side: EAST
		^port.index: 1
		
		label "Port 1"
		label "[-]"
	}
	port P2 {
		^port.side: EAST
		^port.index: 2
		
		label "Port 2"
	}
	port P3 {
		^port.side: EAST
		^port.index: 3
		
		label "Port 3"
	}
}

node T1
node T2
node T3

edge N1.P1->T1
edge N1.P2->T2
edge N1.P3->T3
```

With P1's second label active, this is the result:

![screen shot 2018-02-27 at 10 37 01](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7465584/36721253-a9bc0d32-1baa-11e8-84f9-dfa7fe9f0e20.png)

Without the second label, the surrounding port space above and below the ports is equal (as it should be). With the second label, it is not.

```
graph G1
elk.direction: RIGHT
hierarchyHandling: SEPARATE_CHILDREN
algorithm: org.eclipse.elk.layered
node N1 {
	layout [

		size: 100, 100
	]
	insideSelfLoops.activate: true
	portConstraints: FIXED_SIDE
	port P2 {
		layout [
			size: 20, 20
		]
		side: WEST

	port P4 {
		layout [

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
Layered: Fix inside self loops with ports on the same side. #297

This commit relaxes the constraints put on in-layer edges a bit.
Usually, we expected in-layer edges to always connect a regular node to
a dummy node (that's how we handle inverted ports, which was the reason
for introducing in-layer edges in the first place). With this commit,
they can also connect two external port dummies.

Signed-off-by: Christoph Daniel Schulze <cds@informatik.uni-kiel.de>

issues.title: NPE when combining cross-hierarchy edges, selfloops and splines
issues.body:
Take the following example:
```
hierarchyHandling: INCLUDE_CHILDREN
//edgeRouting: SPLINES

node A1
node A2 {
	node B1
}
edge A2 -> A2
edge A1 -> A2.B1
```
If the `edgeRouting: SPLINES` is activated, a NPE is thrown.
```
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at org.eclipse.elk.alg.layered.p4nodes.bk.BKAligner.insideBlockShift(BKAligner.java:197)
	at org.eclipse.elk.alg.layered.p4nodes.bk.BKNodePlacer.process(BKNodePlacer.java:230)
	at org.eclipse.elk.alg.layered.p4nodes.bk.BKNodePlacer.process(BKNodePlacer.java:1)
	at org.eclipse.elk.alg.layered.ElkLayered.hierarchicalLayout(ElkLayered.java:237)

	at org.eclipse.elk.alg.layered.LayeredLayoutProvider.layout(LayeredLayoutProvider.java:58)
	at org.eclipse.elk.core.RecursiveGraphLayoutEngine.layoutRecursively(RecursiveGraphLayoutEngine.java:183)
	at org.eclipse.elk.core.RecursiveGraphLayoutEngine.layout(RecursiveGraphLayoutEngine.java:60)
	at org.eclipse.elk.core.service.DiagramLayoutEngine.layout(DiagramLayoutEngine.java:682)
	at org.eclipse.elk.core.service.DiagramLayoutEngine.layout(DiagramLayoutEngine.java:614)
	at org.eclipse.elk.core.service.DiagramLayoutEngine$1.execute(DiagramLayoutEngine.java:382)
	at org.eclipse.elk.core.service.util.MonitoredOperation$1.run(MonitoredOperation.java:236)

issues.title: EdgeRouterFactory yields memory leak
issues.body:
The `GraphConfigurator` creates a new `EdgeRouterFactory` for every layout run:
```
algorithmAssembler.setPhase(LayeredPhases.P5_EDGE_ROUTING,
        EdgeRouterFactory.factoryFor(lgraph.getProperty(LayeredOptions.EDGE_ROUTING)));
```

The created edge router instance, say `SplineEdgeRouter`, is then cached within the `AlgorithmAssembler`. Since it's a new factory every time, caching is broken in `AlgorithmAssembler#retrieveProcessor`. 

```
if (enableCaching) {
            if (cache.containsKey(factory)) {
[...]
```

issues.title: elkt serializer has issues with certain characters
issues.body:
The `elkg` file below results in the error below. The issue is that `+`, `-`, and `>` are no viable characters for the ID rule in `elkt`.

```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="ASCII"?>
<graph:ElkNode xmi:version="2.0" xmlns:xmi="http://www.omg.org/XMI" xmlns:graph="http://www.eclipse.org/elk/ElkGraph">
  <children identifier="barrier_t73>>t85+t86-to">
  </children>
</graph:ElkNode>
```

```
Error while converting the selected graph.
Error while converting value 'barrier_t73>>t85+t86-to' for grammar rule 'ID' to string via ValueConverter.
Caused By: org.eclipse.xtext.conversion.ValueConverterException: ID 'barrier_t73>>t85+t86-to' contains invalid characters: '+' (0x2b), '-' (0x2d), '>' (0x3e)
Semantic Object: ElkNode.children[0]->ElkNode
URI: platform:/resource/bla/bugx.elkt
EStructuralFeature: graph::ElkGraphElement.identifier
```

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
Fixed: IllegalStateException in DiagramLayoutEngine. #172

The DiagramLayoutEngine called done() on a progress monitor even if it
was not sure whether that monitor had even been started. Now we only
call done() if we're quite sure that it has.

issues.title: NPE in LGraphUtil#createExternalPortDummy
issues.body:
One of the arguments of the `LGraphUtil#createExternalPortDummy` method is `portPosition`. The port position is used whenever port constraints are at least fixed order. 

In `CompoundGraphPreprocessor#createExternalPortDummy` the method above is called with `null` for `portPosition`. As soon as a hierarchical node has fixed order ports, an NPE is thrown.

issues.title: NPE when loading graphs that contain unknown properties
issues.body:
The XMI graph loading code currently sets all option values to `LayoutOptionProxy` instances. The layout option keys, however, are passed to the meta data service to obtain a `LayoutOptionData` instance, which might be `null`. This is the case if the necessary meta data are not available (yet).

If that is the case, the loading code should simply create a blank property with the (currently) unknown layout option ID. This will prevent NPEs and retain information that might be useful later.

Also, we should add a method `resolveProperties(...)` that triggers resolving proxies. It should be able to either drop unresolvable properties silently, or fail with an exception.

issues.title: Memory leak in Execution Time View
issues.body:
The execution time view is notified by the layout kernel whenever a layout run has completed. It then adds the root progress monitor of that layout run to the list of executions to be shown. Sadly, the root progress monitor keeps references to a whole lot of things, among them the layout mapping. This keeps the layout graph and the original view model from being garbage collected.

The solution will probably be to traverse the progress monitor hierarchy, extract the information to be shown in the view, and keep those around in light-weight objects.

_This ticket originated from the KIELER ticket [KIPRA-1532](https://rtsys.informatik.uni-kiel.de/jira/browse/KIPRA-1532)._

issues.title: INCLUDE_CHILDREN and FIXED_ORDER
issues.body:
There's an issue with `FIXED_ORDER` port constraints on compound nodes when hierarchy handling is set to `INCLUDE_CHILDREN`.

The following .kgt yields a null pointer due to `portPosition` being `null` which is explicitly passed as `null` via a parameter. 

```
at org.eclipse.elk.alg.layered.graph.LGraphUtil.createExternalPortDummy(LGraphUtil.java:839)
```

```
properties: 
    org.eclipse.elk.hierarchyHandling = INCLUDE_CHILDREN

knode n0 {
    properties:
        org.eclipse.elk.portConstraints = FIXED_ORDER
    knode n1
}
knode n2 {
    kedge (-> n1)
} 
```

issues.title: Problems resolving layout option IDs in .elkm files
issues.body:
Sometimes the .elkm editor fails to resolve layout option IDs in `support` declarations. For instance:

```
algorithm awesome(AwesomeLayoutProvider) {
    supports org.eclipse.elk.spacing.node
}
```

Sometimes, the ELK SDK fails to generate code because it was unable to resolve the layout option ID. Restarting Eclipse does not help. Reinstalling Eclipse does. Also, options declared locally in the same .elkm file can be resolved perfectly fine.

Is there a known cause for this problem and some way for fixing it?

issues.title: elkm files do not allow negative values for default and bounds
issues.body:
Trying to set a negative `default` or `lowerBound` value in an elkm file raises an error. 

The used grammar rule is `('default' '=' defaultValue=XExpression)?`.
